ReviewList.Text: The Winter Sea is wonderful. It is exactly the kind of historical fiction that I love reading. The story is about a writer in the present time who travels to Scotland and stays at a cottage in Cruden Bay (between Aberdeen and Edinburgh) near Slain Castle to research materials for her novel about the Jacobite uprising of 1708. (King James (Catholic) was exiled from the English throne to France when Mary and William became King and Queen (Mary was James' daughter) at the request of the English people. King James died in France in 1700, but his son James (aka The Pretender) with the help of the French King invaded Scotland to try to reclaim the crown.) This was the period of the first Jacobite uprising, historical materials for which are hard to come by, as there were many cover-ups, betrayals, etc. Ms. Kearsley gets better with each book she writes. I was reminded pleasantly of Lady Dorothy Dunnett's writing style in which fictional characters are interwoven with real people and events. This book was so much like Lady Dunnett's Checkmate, her six book of the Lymond Chronicles, except that Kearsley is so much easier to read. I loved this book.

At my age, I'll just say over six decades, I have read a few books in my time.  Some of my favorite books being, West With the Night, by Beryl Markham; Sena Jeter Nashlund's, Ahab's Wife, One Thousand White Women by Jim Fergus, Outlander by Diana Gabaldon; The Red Tent, Cutting for Stone, The Help, Sarah's Key I could keep going but you can tell the kind of books I like from that sampling.  Well I have never been so emotionally involved in a book like I was with Winter Sea.  I can hardly find words to tell what a fantastic read this was.  All I can say, and I do love to write myself, is that I wish I could tell a story the way Susanna Kearsley does!

Having just finished a long historical novel I must admit, I wasn't sure I was ready to jump into another one, but once I got absorbed into Sophia's story, I was glad I did. Hard to put down and the ending was absolutely perfect. Nice to read a book that is romantic, captivating, and intersting without needing the use of sex, violence, or foul language. Highly recommend!

I got this book for my Kindle after reading many of the reviews and seeing the high number of 5-star ratings. I was very disappointed. Actually, I was very bored. Nothing happens in this book. Page after page of boredom. The premise was fantastic. The writing is quite good. The progression of the story is extremely dull and repetitive. I wanted to love it. I was looking for a book to rival Outlander, but this wasn't it.

I read this book thinking it might come close to Diana Gabaldon's books. I was expecting way too much. I had a very hard time getting through this story and cannot believe I actually finished it. The writing is poor, the characters are shallow and boring, and the story is utterly predictable. Not much else to say.

I really wanted to like this book but found it dull.  The story was well-constructed and I liked the author's style.  However, the characters were two-dimensional, the main historic event lacked suspense, and the romance between the present day and past lacked passion.

Yawning!  I wanted to love this book and was excited to read it based on others reviews.  I made it 25% through and was thoroughly bored. I consistently fell asleep while trying to finish the book.  While it was well writen, nothing much happened in the first 1/4 of the book.  I love historical fiction, but this one is a real snoozer.

I like how the author transitions from past to present and I like the characters. This book doesn't really "go anywhere". I was hoping for a sweeping romantic tale ala the outlander but this just left me flat. Also, a women in our book club called this " the baptist romance" because there are no intimate scenes...none.

It always amazes me when an author can take historical facts and weave a good fiction story into it. I thought the premise of an author writing a historical novel becoming the novel was well... a novel idea. I thoroughly enjoyed this book with the setting and characters especially. The only reason for not the full 5 starts was the sometimes long historical infill. At times it did feel like a history lesson. Good story, well written, well thought out and that is much appreciated!

Disappointing purchase. Heavy with detail that leaves no room for the reader to experience the story along with the characters.  Laborious reading through historical minutia.  Sadly, the book was easy to put down, and hard to pick up again.  Included in the plot are some writing tips which might interest budding writers, but will not entertain readers.

Kearsley blends old and new in a tale rich in genuine historical events and people, vivid landscapes and locations, and romance.  Tears shed for hard choices and tested dreams; Kearsley's rhythm and tension will leave you wondering when day turned to night.

Don't get me wrong, it's a good book but I thought at the outset it would be a fantastic book.  The main premise, that of "genetic memory" was only referred to, never really resolved.  I think there was potential to make something very interesting out of that supposition but I kept waiting for it and it never occurred.  It took me a long time to finish this book (I generally read 1.5-2 books per week-this took several weeks).  I'd recommend it but not with the enthusiasm I had hoped to.

I bought this book based off of the star rating and the good reviews of other readers.  I'm sorry I did.  This book was so predictable!!  I knew as she was drawing the map of the Slains Castle that she would find it was exactly as the orginal before I even read this based off of what had happened so far.  I LOVE to read and will read just about anything but right now I am forcing myself to finish this just so that my money wasn't competely wasted.

Oh, dear. I'm going to be one of those reviewers. You know, I never write a review but...I feel compelled. I am a reader of historical fiction and yet this one is slooooow. I enjoy description. I enjoy poetic description. I do not enjoy overly lengthy, simply there for the word count description. So much so that I skimmed...*I skimmed!*...through quite a few parts to get back to the semblance of plot. I have read several of Ms. Kearsley's books and thoroughly enjoyed them, with few exceptions. I cannot in good conscience say that I enjoyed this one. While historical fiction is my genre, this was a poor version of literature disguised mostly as a grade school teacher's rawhide lecture on Scottish History for Dummies. The way the main characters removed themselves from the story to dryly rehash the backstory leaves little to be desired. And while I'm not here for the romance, the love story not only wasn't believable but not romantic at all. I felt no connection or desire to see them together nor anxiety for them to reunite. My conclusion? Blah. Sadly, I finished out of compulsion not out of obsession, like you would any good book.

My husband could spend hours and hours reading about history.  I usually get bored with any book dealing with history.  Not this time.  Susanna Kearnsley made this story so exciting to me.  It was a joy to learn about the Jacobites and how they fought so courageously to try to bring back their beloved King to the throne.  The historical facts were told through the eyes of the characters, which were real and believable and nicely developed.  I liked how the author would alternate between the present day--when the story was told by a young American writer Carrie who moves to Scotland to write a historical fiction book--and the past when it is told from the eyes of Carrie's ancestor, Sophia, who is living in northeast Scotland in a castle in the early 1700s.  Their is a beautiful love story in both settings.  I fell in love with the writing style of Susanna kearnsley and her characters.  Beautifully written book.  I want to read more of her books--i hope she has more.  I am hooked on her writing style.

I thought this book was incredibly slow paced. Nothing really happened at all, and even the aspects of romance took basically one hundred pages to start. The relationship between Carrie and Graham was cute, and that's the only reason it even gets 2 stars.

I bought this book on a whim when it was on sale, and I am so glad I did! It's the story of novelist Carrie McClelland, who is successful and famous for her historical fiction. She wants to write her next novel on the Jacobites, but can't seem to make the words flow. But one day, as she's driving up the coast, she sees the ruins of Slains castle, and is inspired. She settles in a cottage nearby and begins writing, playing with characters from her own ancestry, believing that she is taking liberties with history. But throughout the writing process, she begins to have strange memories, and when she writes down things she never read about, but later prove to have actually happened, Carrie is disturbed. Could such a thing as genetic memory exist, and what does that mean for her ancestors? I found this book to be very intriguing, entertaining, and so easy to become lost in.

Listen, don't get me wrong, I finished this book but it was a struggle. I was really expecting some major revelations and consequences for the main character but nothing happened. It is like she discovered she was psychic and just said, "well that's nice" I thought Susanna Kearsley's writing style was polished and easy to read, but the content was just lacking. I love historical fiction, but this is not where it's at.

I really hated for this book to end.  It was really beautifully written.  And, the whole book was "not to put down".  It was seamless from current time to the 1700 era.  I read at night so I could not "force" myself to go to sleep until 1AM...cutoff time.  I am sorry that more Susanna Kearsley books are not on Kindle.  Enjoy!!  Linda Tucker Cormier  a native California dreamer....

For me, the best kind of historical fiction is that in which you wish that you could get to know the characters a little better, even when the book has ended.  The ones where you go out and look up information on the time period on the internet to learn more about the era and the people.  This was that kind of book.  I highly recommend it.

As a fan of Outlander, I had expected this book to live up to its hype since so it was recommended so highly by people who also purchased the Gabaldon series. It wasn't even close to comparison. There were no similarities in writing style, plot or otherwise. I find it hard to believe that the intellectual types, history lovers, or romance fans loved this book as much as they did. I also bought this for my step-mother and she also had a difficult time finishing it. I guess I was expecting too much from this 'novel'. It read more like a trashy romance novel - unfortunately lacking the trash that would have made it worth-while.

I liked Sophia, at first. But then she became a selfish, whiny (I have nothing to live for)sissy.  When it didn't feel like I was in a history class, I felt like I was in the middle of a harlequim romance novel. I flipped through the final 30 pages.  If the ending was going to be so cheesy, at least take your child with you!

I recently finishing A Discovery of Witches by Deborah Harkness and looked to the reviews of that book for suggestions for my next read. Boy was I glad I did! Although it took me a few chapters to get into, I absolutely loved The Winter Sea and will definitely be reading other books by Susanna Kearsley.

I literally could not put this book down and stayed up way too late reading it.  I bought it based on the excellent reviews, with which I completely agreed.  It was very well written, with interesting characters based on solid historical research.  A pleasure to read!
Although I had predicted the ending from the beginning, and the way it is written a bit repetitive, I still found this to be a great love story and the history is a bonus!  I would recommend this!

I have to be honest and say that it was hard for me to get connected to this book.  The time travel and dialect was difficult for me to grab a hold of.  I haven't been wanting to read books that take actual concentration to read.  However, once I was able to focus and got sucked in, well, I LOVED it!  I have not had a book move me as much as this one did in years!!!  Ach, not at all what I expected!  This is the first book I have read of Susanna's and I'm hooked.  I got so wrapped up into the characters, I truly started to care for them.  The historic detail made me want to travel to Scotland, now!!!  This book is defiantly worth the investment of time.  What I mean as time, it's not a skim through book to pass time.  It's a book where the characters come to life.  It takes you to another place, another time.  I haven't felt this much passion for a book in years!  This book rekindled the historian and hopeless romantic in me that has been dormant for a long time.  I absolutely fell in love with it!

This was one of those books I chose to read because of all the positive reviews.  This is my first Susana Kearsley novel, but I read summaries and reviews of her other books, and this seemed like a good choice.  Unfortunately, I was never engaged. I read at least 25% of the book before giving up.  The story and the characters seemed to get more boring.  I decided to go back to the reviews and filter 1 and 2 star rating to see why these readers did not enjoy the book.  I totally agreed with their reviews.  I decided not to finish the book even though the plot sounded slightly more interesting than what I had already read.  There is no conflict or zing.  I did not like either main heroine nor did I think there was any chemistry between any characters.  There are too many 4 and 5 star books I'll never get to so I did not feel like plodding through this one, and I'm pretty sure I won't regret regaining my reading time to read better books.

Here's the thing, if you write a romance novel, it needs to be romantic.  If it is to be historical, it needs to be history.  If it is to be a character study, it needs fascinating three dimensional characters.  Sadly, it missed the boat on all three, when I think it could have been all three.  The characters had little chemistry, and were flat, the history was stretched, and the plot was lackadaisical.  I was disappointed and kept reading because I expected it to get better.  The writer has a lovely writing style and I just kept hoping that it would warm up, move more smartly or *something*.  Then these new characters kept popping up with little introduction and behaved predictably and in ways that served the plot. Darn.  Here are my recommendations for substitutes:  If you are looking for some mystery and intrigue, try "The Woman in White" by Wilkie Collins.  If you want romance; "North and South" by Elizabeth Gaskell (very swoon-worthy), and if you want history, try anything by Alison Weir.  Seriously, she'll take you into history and keep you there.

Plain and simple, I loved this story... I haven't finished the book yet but I know I'm close, because my Kindle says I'm 90% through the book.  I'm already in mourning over the end of this book.  I loved the storytelling that happened here.  I was wrapped up from the first chapter and obviously having a hard time letting go now that it's ending.  This was a romance, historical, time travel book, all wrapped in one, that wasn't either raunchy in it's romance or left you wanting more.  The romance was very tastefully done.  And trust me, I like my raunchy romance, but I can also appreciate when the writer doesn't make the book about heavy amounts of sex. Overall, I cannot recommend this book enough to those who love those type of genres.

I just finished The Winter Sea and I have say that it is one of the best books I have read in a very long time. Ms. Kearsley has written an intelligent, touching story filled with historical facts and enduring love. I felt as if I were there, on the scene, an eyewitness to history while at the same time watching a love story develop both in the past and in the present.  What a perfect blend of fact and fiction.  A beautiful story of love and loss and hope that touched a range of emotions in me and had me, at times, reaching for a tissue. I know I will be thinking about this book and the wonderful people within its pages for a long time to come.  If you love history, if you love strong characters with strong beliefs about country and family you will, I promise, love this story. Bravo and thank you, Susanna, for this gem of a page turner.

This is a beautiful read. The two love stories past and present interweave effortlessly. The ending chapters brought me to tears...poignant says it all. The history lags a little in places, but the overall characters and plot outweigh any slowness in these areas. NEAT SIDENOTE: The author's website has pictures of actual buildings and landscapes in Scotland where this story takes place. I read a plot summary that said, "the modern day heroine channels the memories from the past. That summary seems to suggest a paranormal plot line and that was not how I interpreted the book at all. It really is a story of how a love can be so strong and true to literally transcend time. Definitely worth reading!!!!!

I chose this book because I really enjoy Susanna Kearsley's writing.  She mostly writes about fictional characters living in the British Isles during the 1700's.  As with most historical fiction, many characters that touched their lives were actual, soldiers of that era.  In "The Winter Sea," the story is about a (fictional) modern day writer of historical fiction, who seems to have a special gift for imagining the scenes of her story, only to find out through her research, that the stories turned out to be true, including names, dates and places.  Part love story, it is set in Scotland as they were trying to return the exiled King James to his rightful Scottish throne.

This book is amazing. I read a lot and this isn't my usual genre or style of book. I didn't really even know what I was getting into. I am so glad I took a chance on this. It is probably my favorite book, and has been for a few years now. Ms Kearsley very carefully crafts two amazing stories simultaneously in this book and it sucks you right in. She is a very talented writer and this is an excellent example of that. It even manages to be incredibly romantic without ever being graphic.  I recommend this book to just about anyone who asks, including family members and my mother. I just keep coming back to this one, and highly recommend it to anyone!

What a story!  The book kept me enthralled until the very end!  I liked the storyline where the main character is an author, and how she is writing a book that took place in the past and how it related to the present.  The main character is likable and so real, as is the main character in the book she is writing about.  I could not put the book down.  There is a lot of history in the book and it did not turn me off at all, if anything it worked to make sense of the present.  I enjoyed it so much and I recommend it because it has mystery, romance, and history.  You will not be disappointed!

This type of book is a different genre for me (I am a get-the-villain type of reader) but I am thrilled with this genre--or more specifically, thrilled with the style in which this author presents a historical novel.  I am of Scottish descent and enjoy learning a bit about the early 1700s in Scotland and the attempt to return Scotland's King James the VII (known in England as King James the II) to the throne.  The author cleverly and seamlessly weaves the story between present day and those days of cloak and dagger needed to attempt the return of James.

I was really disappointed in this book.  The many 5 star reviews, the description on the back....it all sounded great - but I had a very hard time getting through it and ended up skimming most of it after page 100 or so.  I thought it was boring and did not capture any of the suspense the back description promised. Even how she was afraid of the path up to her house turned out to be nothing. While the description of Scotland was in great detail -I found it all very boring to read.  There was no intrique between the two brothers, no intrigue in the past.  Very lackluster.  I am surprised at all the five star reviews, I really am.

When I realized this was more romance than history, I almost stopped reading it. However, there was enough history to keep me going. I enjoyed the chapters that took place in the past more than the present. (I'll admit to being a little intolerant of writers who make their main characters writers, as was the case with the present day chapters). If you want some real less-romantic Scottish history, try Nigel Tranter's work. If you like your history heavily mixed with romantic love (no bodice-ripping or sexual description here), you might like this.

This was a first for me, reading Susanna Kearsley. I am glad I did. Maybe it was the way the story was written or maybe it was just a really good book but I thoroughly enjoyed it. I liked the banter between Carrie and the rest of the current time characters and I loved the historical story about Sofia and John. I LOVED how their story ended and very few books could make me shed the tears I did.  I feel like I got a two for one reading this book.  The flow was great, the stories wonderful and I would recommend it to anyone who likes an easy read.

Loved this book.  I was taken aback at first by Susanna Kearsley's love for really long sentences.  But once I got into the flow of the book (trust me ... it doesn't take long), I was hooked.  I tend to love most things that have an historical element to them.  This was a great book with some unexpected turns along the way.  The romantic part was well done ... neither understated or over the top.  Nicely done.  For the first time in a really long time I had a hard time focusing on other things besides reading.  Nicely done.

Well-written with the finest local descriptions that make this retelling of a war story full of humanity and understanding.  Not for war historians but for those interested in learning something about the Scots' struggle for independence. Descriptions of people, events, and places so vivid I felt myself in the midst of it all.  Twists and turns in the tale make for an I-can't-put-it-down story of suspense, loss, and love.  Highly recommended and so glad it became an American publication--can't imagine having missed it.

I just finished The Winter Sea and while I don't usually write reviews on books I've read, I feel compelled just to say a few words about this one.  It's not very often that a book will bring me to tears but when Sophia was leaving Slains and Anna, I couldn't stop the tears from falling.  Leaving behind not only Anna, but the Countess of Erroll as well, who'd become so much like a mother to her was incredibly moving.  Have a few tissues ready when you get to this part because you may just need them.

Susanna Kearsley is my new favorite author!  I was completely taken into the story and appreciated how well this book was researched.  The fantasy twist of "genetic memory" was an intriguing device to view the lives of folks who lived 300 years ago. My kids love when I find books like this because they know I will step away from the usual rules, like screen limits, so that I can have the time to finish my book! Am now onto the sequel, Firebird, and we'll see if I like it just as well.

It's been nearly a year since I have read a novel worthy of review. I read on average a book a day and must say that Sophia and Carrie's stories are a beautifully woven tale. Ripe with history and intrigue I anxiously turned each page. The romance for each heroine was so carefully spun as to keep me engaged and anticipating each woman's journey. I loved the similarities and the bridge that crossed time and entwined their lives and their loves. Thank you for the gift of a wonderful escape.

True to her talent for combining history with endearing romance, Kearsley interweaves the story of an actual event ini which King James attempts to return from France to take back his crown and the story of romance between the two historians dedicated to learning details about this event. She paints beautiful word pictures of the Scottish coast, builds character who are real, and, with a touch of supernatural, blends the stories perfectly. Again, and excellent read from Ms Kearsley.

If you like history, particularly Scottish history, and if you're a romantic at heart, you'll like this book.  But I must stress--you have to enjoy history.  Otherwise, you might get bogged down before you reach the end, which is page 527!  Yes, it's long, but I was captivated throughout.  Two stories run simultaneously, one in the present and one in the 1700s; and, they are connected.  This is not a "beach read," but it is definitely a "curl up with a hot cup of tea" kind of novel.

I absolutely adore this book.  This is the first novel by Susanna Kearsley that I read, and it hooked me almost imediately.  The historical aspects of the book are fascinating in their content and in the perspective they are told in.  The peices of the story set in the present are equally interesting, and the characters and the plot keep the reader guessing. If I have one complaint, its that the plot seems to drag in some places, but not to the point that I ever stopped reading.

I have bought many books and this is the first time I feel compelled to write a review.  The story within the story technique reminds me of A.S. Byatt's Possession which also took hold of me.  I really am grateful to the the author for taking me away from life and writing a book that I could not put down (I read it in two nights and in the car and everywhere I had a few minutes).  I would have liked the narrator's first ending, but I enjoyed how she surprised me at the end.

I usually don't give 5 stars to books..but this one deserves it.  I love books that keep me thinking about them after I've finished.  Almost a week later, I'm still thinking about this one.  Since I do genealogy, I understand the feeling of wanting an ancestor to send me messages about their life.  I started out preferring the modern day story, but soon found myself looking forward to the flashbacks more.  What a great story!  I can't wait to read more of her books.

I enjoyed this book although it took me a little longer to get into then normal. Basically there are two different plots happening at the same time yet in two different historical periods. At first I found it annoying to keep jumping back and forth between the present and 300 years ago, but the author tied them together nicely in the end. It covered an interesting period of history which I knew very little about, so it was nice to learn something along the way.

This was one of the first Kindle books that I bought and I'm not sure why I did not read it earlier.  I liked the mxi of present and past, and the sweetness of the romances. I thought the writing was of a higher quality than my usual romance reads, and it was a pleasure to read something that was more about the story than about sex.  I find the historical period confusing, and I appreciated how the author brought in the history along eith the plot development.

Instead of a synopsis (many reviews have already covered this), let me just state that I loved this book. I started out fascinated by Carolyn's story, and then I was pulled into Sophia's. Although the themes are by no means lightweight, the book makes a quick read that won't depress you. I enjoyed the read on my e-reader, and then ordered the paperback so I can have it on my bookshelf as well - I'll definitely be picking up more of this author's work!

I found this book to be well-written, engaging and based on actual facts. It is a book inside a book and both 'books' held my attention. I was sorry to have it end and kept thinking about the story lines for some days afterwards. The characters from both books also continue to pass in and out of my memory. I think this was a good read and would recommend it whether or not one is interested in historical fiction. It would also make a good film.

This author was new to me, so I had no idea what to expect.  The story was a little slow getting started, but, in the end, was one of those stories that I looked forward to picking up at the end of each day, when I had a chance to relax and ponder.  The story was beautifully written and the characters well developed.  As soon as I finish this review, I am searching Amazon for more books by this author.  Definitely a very good find!

For a historical romance, it was a little heavy on the history. There were a few too many very long passages that read like a fairly stiff lecture for me. The story within a story device works, but I would have preferred the characters on both sides of the isle be a little less stock. Engaging they were, just not terribly original. All that said, she's a good writer. She just needs to break out of the mold and take some chances.

This novel had it all for me: a setting in Scotland by the sea, historical events (the attempt of James, the son of exiled King James of England, to reclaim the crown by invading Scotland), romance, and a parallel of two characters in different time periods.  This is the first time I have read a novel by Susanna Kearsley, who writes extremely well in description and plot formation, and I definitely want to read more from her.

I'd never heard of Susanna and serendiptiously came across Every Secret Thing. I couldn't put it down, so I thought I'd try another of hers - The Winter Sea. This is such a good book, well written, evocative of Scotland and the setting is exciting. Throw a lot of romance and a time travel parallel and you've got it made. A thoroughly wonderful tale and I will read more. These books have got me hooked on historical fiction!

Like Gabaldon' s book Outlander, this book weaves an enchanting love story with a strong, resilient female character like Claire. However, it lacks the historical detail and accuracy of Outlander. The characters are not nearly as well developed and multifaceted in this book either. That said, it is an enjoyable read. The author skillfully weaves the past and present throughout the book with very few awkward transitions.

This is not my usual type of book. Historical fiction usually bores me. The Winter Sea fascinated me. I had to read the ending by placing my kindle in a file a work, while pretending I was analyzing an account! You will get a bit of everything in this amazing story of loyalties and family. Go ahead and buy it. Do not think twice. I can no longer write this review...I'm Too anxious to read my next Susanna Kearsley novel.

I very much loved this story.  The author wove what is essentially two books together so seamlessly that I never felt jarred when moving from one to the other.  The imagery was evocative and elegant, without being too flowery or over-the-top, and the overall writing was beautiful.  I loved, loved, loved the historical detail and how real that part of the story felt.  Definitely going to be one of my all-time favorites.

I put this book in my shopping cart, as I love all Kearsley's books. However, I realized that I had already read it under the title "Sophia's Secret". I had once previously ordered a Kearsley book, only to find it was one I had already read under a different title. This sometimes happens with English vs. American editions - just a word of advice --- ENJOY her books, but make sure you aren't ordering a duplicate.

This book moved slowly at first and then grabbed hold of me to the end. Susanna Kearsley wove artfully together time long past and current.  This historical fiction held me captive to the end.  I experienced joy and sadness.  History became thrilling with romance mixed in.  WINTER SEA is at the top of my 'favorites list' and I wonder if Kearsley has another book that might takes its place.  I aim to find out!

I think "The Winter Sea" is the fourth or fifth of Ms. Kearsley's books that I've read, and although I've enjoyed them all very much, I'd say this is my favorite so far.  It has time travel and a timeless romance; it has history, but it is fiction.  The love story is grand and passionate without being graphic and prurient.  Yup!  I liked "The Winter Sea" and recommend it highly.

My first by this author, and I enjoyed it so much I've purchased several of her other works. I enjoy the historical novel as an alternate to biographies and modern novels, and this combines those elements within a modern-day tale. The romantic part of the storyline is  not too much to denigrate or detract from the overall quality. I'm not a fast or avid reader, and this kept me enthralled.

The Winter Sea is a great book for those who like a good romance (without the explicit sexual details), a little mystery and a bit of historical background.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book!  Kearsley is an adept writer.  Her characters are well-developed, her plot moves along nicely and her historical backdrop is researched well.  This book was an extremely satisfying read.

This was a very interesting book with some characters I really liked. I listened to part and read part which I think made keeping straight some of the historical characters a bit of work but I really enjoyed both stories. I was intrigued enough to do a bit of research on my own (and really makes me want to go to Scotland!). I will seek out more books by this author.

This was a nice read. It sometimes read more like a history lesson but without that I'd have no grasp on the danger experienced by those at Slains Castle.  Her imagry was bright and lush-I felt like I was there on the edge of the Scottish cliffs with her.  If you're searching for heavy romance this may not be for you....but I loved it.  Subtle and elegant.

I just tried one of Ms. Kearsley's books because it was on sale, but I was sucked in. I stayed up all night reading it. Ms. Kearsley has a beautiful writing style that draws you in. The book has a combination of history, time travel, adventure, and romance. One of the most sweetly romantic books I've read in a while. I can't wait to start her other books.

Susanna Kearsley has become a new favorite author, having never read her books. This was written in such an enchanting way, that I felt a part of the story -- a trip to Scotland and a bit of time travel into the past of royal dynasties, castles, war, and finding true love. I am looking forward to reading more of her books

I've read two other books by Susanna Kearsley and I liked them a lot. I find Winter Sea to be boring. I don't like how the story jumps from the person writing the story to the actual story, and goes back and forth between the two. The history part of it is long and boring as well. There's a lot of conversation and not much action or mystery.
This is the first book I have read by this author.  I was enchanted and could not put this book down.  I would give it 10 stars if I could.  Can't wait to read more by this author.

I usually love historical fiction, however, I had such a tough time with this bit of history.  It was boring and hard to keep track of all the different people thrown at you all at once.  I enjoyed the story line but the history confounded it for me.  I had to re-start the book twice in order to get all the facts in order, but eventually just kept plowing through and glossed over much of the history lesson.  I wasn't totally dissatisfied, but it was just okay for me.
this is another one that I've downloaded to my kindle and kind of go back to when I don't have anything else to read
The story was entertaining but was to close to formulaic romances for my taste, rich author meets ideal man, mirrors characters in her story....a little hard to swallow.  Still I read it through.

I love books that teach me something and at the same time transport me into the world of fiction.  This book is history and fantasy at its best.  I was so taken by the cast of characters from Slain's Castle who were such a part of the movement to return the exiled King James to Scotland, that while reading this book I googled everything from Slain's Castle and photos of Cruden Bay...and YouTubed the music to listen to while reading. Adding the occasional use of Doric dialect deepened my experience of both 1700 century and present day Scottland.

Really enjoyed the dual storylines.  Had a little trouble keeping track of the historical events.  The romance was tastefully described.  Both stories took me away for a total escape by the descriptions of the landscape.

Kearsley really nailed it in this one: characters, plot, mood, landscape, history, politics, the works, wrapping in all up in a gorgeous package. Unlike another book of hers which is hard to review without a BIG spoiler, she created a hugely satisfying ending and indulged the reader by stringing it our luxuriously. When I've invested many pages and much emotion in a book I need time and details to absorb the conclusion. She gave me that this time along with an excellent, rich, evocative read. Five Stars and not one less!

The Winter Sea was my introduction to Susanna Kearsley, and I'm so glad I found her. Her writing is wonderful and her characters endearing - not to mention the historical accuracy you'll find within the pages. Just when you think you know where she's going with the plot, she throws in a twist. I hope you like it as much as I do.

The book itself was a wonderful read, I myself enjoyed the historical portion greatly.  I believe other reviewers have given more than enough justice to the story.  I just wanted to comment specifically that if you are considering this as a Kindle purchase, that the Kindle version that I read was flawless (as far as I could tell) and that is quite a rarity among the ebooks I have purchased.  Kudos to the publisher for putting in equally fine work on the product to match the author's own fine tale, it was quite a pleasure to read.

Those who love historical fiction will LOVE this book.  I had to actually look up some of the history because I didn't know the history surrounding Scotland at that time, but it ended up being explained in the book better than I found on my brief look-see on Wikipedia.  All historical characters in the book except one or two are real and represented accurately according to published history.  I would look up Slains Castle just to get a look at where the book is set--it's amazing!  I definitely reccommend this book!  Enjoy!

This book was such a pleasure to read.  The author provided incredible detail, without becoming boring. It was emotionally touching, without becoming too sugary. Full of historical details and rich, complicated characters that you came to care about.  With the addition of a bit of a supernatural element, it was a perfect story.  Thank you, Susanna Kearsley!

I read this following Diana Gabaldon's masterpiece Outlander series.  I enjoyed the book, but found it rather predictable.  It was easy reading and I would recommend it with the note that it is not nearly as deep, rich or complex as Gabaldon's stories.  I enjoyed it enough to want to read more of Kearsley's work and was disappointed to find this is the only title available as an ebook.

I enjoyed this book.  It was like 2 books in one the way the storyline flowed from one era to to current.  Some of the details of what was going on I skimmed over (this king and that king and this battle and that battle), I'm not to sure all of that was needed to go with the story line.  But others may have been interested in it all.

I'm not usually one to enjoy a historical romance of any caliber, BUT found The Winter Sea nearly impossible to put down.  I fell in love with the setting and the characters and it has inspired me to dream about visiting Scottland one day.  I was transported to a place I've never been and was sad to reach The End.

I like the book, it was not what I expected considering it was promoted if I liked Discovery of Witches; but none the less I did like this book. It was kind of Diana Gabladon light.  Not the depth of either book series but a good enjoyable read. I would like to see the story continue and delve deeper into the history aspect and the characters. The idea that we can return after a life time and find our lovers is a wonderful thought; that I'd like to see expanded.

This is the best book I've read in a long time, and I read a lot.  Two stories, one comtemporary and one historical, are beautifully woven together.  The characters and plots draw you in until it is almost painful to put the book down before finishing.  And when it is finished, you are left with a feeling of well being and satisfaction.  This is the first Susanna Kearsley book I've ever read, but it won't be my last.

While the novel starts a little slow, it quickly picks up pace and envelopes you in a tale that is impossible to put down.  A little romance, a little fantasy, a little mystery, a little deception, a little violence... it's all there.  Very well done!  Excellent read!

I enjoyed the book very much.  Loved the ending.  Found going back and forth from the present to the past distracting at times (a bit too often, but kept your reading).  The history wasn't so technical that you couldn't keep track of who's who.  I did connect with the main characters very well and wished they were real.  Relaxing!

The comparison between Susanna Kearsley and Mary Stewart compelled me to read Winter Sea.  Unfortunately I was terribly disappointed.  There is no comparison.  Kearsley's research and historical detail are gratifying but her characters are one-dimensional.  Particularly her 2 heroines.  They are flat and insipid and there's simply nothing about them to like.  It is therefore very hard to care what happens to them.  I give the book three stars for the interesting historical detail. Kearsley could be a fine writer but I was vastly disappointed with the plot and characters.

This book is now one of my top five favorite books that I have ever read. The way that Susanna makes the book flow, and how she descibes each scene actually makes you feel like you are seeing it for yourself. The transition between Carolyn's "world" and Sophia's was as smooth as silk. It didn't leave me feeling like I was missing anything. This book had me giggling, crying(which I hardly ever do), and actually throwing my hands up and shouting "Yes!" I will be re-reading this book over and over again for years to come I am sure. For anyone who loves history with a wee bit of fiction and romance thrown in. Will love this book. Great job Susanna!

Enjoyed this book on Kindle.  Tried reading paperback but vision problems I can read better on Kindle.  It was so good that had to buy the next book Firebird.  Scotland and the Jacobites trying to help King James to retrieve his rightful role as king.  Sophia, John Moray and all the characters are brought to life in this book.

This story flowed really well.  I enjoyed how the two stories in different time periods are meshed into one.  This was the first book by Susanna Kearsley I'd read, and since then I've ordered some more!  I really like historical fiction and romance...and this hit both of those along with a bit of fantasy.  Good stuff!

The perfect book to read when you're coming down from the Outlanders series. I didn't realize I've read other books by Susanna before and loved them. I'm sure I'll read all the rest of her books. I've already purchased one more. I grew up on Mary Stewart's romance novels and Susanna's books feel like coming home.

I liked the way the author develops two good stories at the same time. The historical factors are also very interesting, you learn a lot about a place and time that are not very common in History. Both stories are a love story but very well writen and in two different centuries.  Somehow, they are both conected.

I had never read this author when I read a recommendation about The Winter Sea in a magazine. I never wanted to put it down from wanting to know what happens next. I am now reading The Firebird which follows Anna as she becomes an adult.  Susanna Kearsley certainly knows how to hold the interest of her readers.

A wonderful, haunting tale of a time little written of. The timeslip premise meshed beautifully, and one does not need to suspend disbelief. An emotionally evocative read. I'm delighted to have discovered this author, and doubly delighted she is a fellow Canadian. I will definitely read her other novels.

First book of hers I've read. I like historical fiction, which initially drew me to this one. The "supernatural" element, and the book-within-a-book added an extra element of fun. But it was the whole style of writing that I enjoyed the most. I'm definitely going to read more of her books now.

I loved this dreamy, historical novel.  It was an easy read, that I really savored.  The tiny touch of magic was just enough to enchant, but didn't throw the novel into the fantasy genre.  This was the first Susanna Kearsley novel I have read, but as soon as I finish this review I will order another.

I enjoyed every aspect of this story.  The characters seemed to come to life from John and Sophia to Graham and Carrie.  I found myself looking for more books about the Scottish rebellion and the would be King James and the Jacobites.  I always enjoy a good historical fiction/suspense/romance.

I found the historical charaters well researched and very interesting. The fictional characters are charming. For anyone with Scots heritage, or a love of the Jacobites, this is a delightful book. I actually read a sequel first, then searched for The Winter Sea to get the whole story.

The story took me on an adventure unlike any I had read regarding time travel. Technically, it wasn't time travel, but just as informative of the past being portrayed. I'm enjoying this author very much while I wait on Diana Gabaldon to finish her 8th book in the Outlander series.

I really enjoyed the beginning. However, it starts to drag miserably. Everything seems a bit too easy for our heroin. She just magically remembers her relatives past life and turns it into an amazing novel. No crazy plot here. I figured out the ending very early. Just blah for me

This is the second book by this author that I read. I have read Shadowy Horses also. Though I enjoyed that book, I loved this one. I would highly recommend this read. The mix of past and present is remarkably done. A great romance novel that combines history and mystery.

A beautiful book. Wonderfully written, Kearsley seamlessly moves the book between past and present. I was unsure of how she would bring the book full circle and stay true to the historical setting of the book but she did! Somehow managing to surprise me with her ending.

Book inside a book, an author explores her own family history while authoring a novel that took place in the early 1700's in Scotland. She finds that she is lead on her journey by her ancestors and while following in her ancestor's steps, meets the love of her life.

While the historical aspect was good, the story seemed to drag on forever. I actually skipped some pages which I very rarely do. Not on my list of favorites. I usually pursue an authors other books when I enjoy the first one, but I'll not be doing that this time.

I read a lot of books and this one really has my heart!  I loved that it was set in Scotland, and had both hear and now and history of Scotland in 1700's.  I was captivated and enchanted, and wanted it to never end.  Now I want more of Susanna Kearsley's  books.

I randomly purchased this book, because the synopsis was intriguing and Amazon had a special deal going on. I have thoroughly enjoyed this book and would recommend it to anyone! I've liked it so much that I've read it more than once, and I rarely ever do that!

I hate long books but I have to say I absolutely LOVED  this this story ! It went so fast and was the most amazing book!  I started reading it late one afternoon and finished it at 5:00 in the morning. I can not wait to read more from Susanna Kearsley!!!!!

This book held my interest from beginning to end. It is at times a tale of war, of intrigue and of romance. The movement between the past and the present is smooth and believable. This novel is a great choice for lovers of history, adventure and romance.

"Let it be, we'll have warmth enough." (Favourite quote.) Oh if you need a romantic blockbuster of a story, this has to be up there with the best. This is my all time best loved novel, almost ever, one which I read time and time again. Set on the stark east coast of Scotland,( close to where I live) lies Slains Castle; a ruinous pile with so much history endless books have been written about it. Carrie McClelland arrives in Cruden Bay to write a novel, a little unsure of how the historical will reveal itself to her but before she has chance to catch her breath, it seems the novel is almost writing itself, as if told by a distant relative from Carrie's past. In the Seventeen hundreds Slains Castle is the epicentre of devious deeds as a group of dedicated followers of King James attempt to smuggle him back from his exile in France to reinstate him on his throne, his rightful place as the King of Scotland. It's 1708, now recorded in history as the doomed attempt of 08. At that time, Sophia finds herself living at Slains in the care of the wonderful Countess after a lifetime of abuse at the hands of her evil Uncle. Among the gathered secret visitors is the dark and brooding John Moray, a spy for the King, an ardent Jacobite follower and dedicated to his cause. What happens in their lifetime resonates forward through the centuries, finding a story of an amazing love within the pages of Carrie's unwritten novel. As Carrie comes to love Cruden Bay she begins to empathise with Sophia's desperate words as she prepared to leave Slains Castle all those centuries ago.."My heart will be forever held in this place"  Oh this story (not wanting to give too much away and spoil it for you) sweeps you away to troubled shores, violent weather, secrets and spies and devious doings from the doomed 08, all told through the words of a girl in love from the turrets of Slains with a back drop of an ever changing winter sea. Its heart breaking, thrilling and the best romance I have ever read since P&P; from Ms Austin. You are captivated as you read this and I promise you a conclusion to end them all, even the hardest of hearts, it's simply breathtaking, Deserving of a whole galaxy of stars!!

Hard to get in to at first... but then hated for it to end!  Characters came to life and it's unusual for me to cry reading a book, but I did.  Highly recommend even though I guessed the plot and there wasn't a big surprise for me.  Still loved it.

I like the way she went back in time and still came back to the present without leaving me baffled.She writes a beautiful story with vivid scenery and characterizations that made me care deeply about them.  I will read more of Susanna Kearsley.

This was an interesting blend of modern and historical settings that meshed together so perfectly, the transitions were effortless. I loved the characters and the author's attention to every detail. Very good book, well written and researched.

What a great summer read this book is!  I very much liked the way the author kept me interested in two stories at the same time. I fell in love with the characters both then and now.  The ending was.....oh, I can're give that away now, can I?

Drew me right in to the world of Scotland in the present and past. The writer deftly handles the transition between centuries as she tells the story of one woman writing about the past and discovers similarities which can't be coincidence.

The thing I liked the most was the intertwining of characters. No, it is not time-travel, as stated in the book's description. No descriptive rape, violence, etc that you usually have to endure in other books. Calm to read. Very good book.

I pushed my book club to pick this book, not having read it, based on the positive reviews. But I'm pretty disappointed in it. The smattering of history is interesting, but all I hear ringing in my head is "Mary Sue! Mary Sue!"

This is a very good book, love the whole theme of the book.  The writing was great it flowed, easy to read even going back and forth from one time to another. I would recommend this book and I will buy her other books.

Not a Christian book, but still had enough to keep me reading.  I have always been fascinated with Scotland (part of my ancestry) and this book had a really unique story within a story.  Well written and a great read.

I thought the whole story was set in the 1700s but in actuality it is set in present day and flashes back to the 1700s. I was looking for purely historical fiction so I felt a bit misled. Not what I was looking for.

Carrie has come to Scotland as part of her research for a new book, a historical fiction covering the attempted return of James to Scotland in 1708. She is enchanted by a ruined castle on her way to her agent's christening, and is shocked to later find that it is integral to her story. She finds herself taking a different perspective on the story and takes some liberties by telling the story through the eyes of a young woman, who she names Sophia. Deciding to stay in Scotland, she rents a cottage, meeting one son of the owner, a widower, on the plane ride over. He is brash and charming, and is intent on winning her over. Carrie becomes deeply involved in her book, writing in an almost trance-like state. She is surprised and disturbed to find that some of the things she thought she made up turn out to be historical fact.  Carrie contacts her father, who has a passion for the family's ancestry, and finds that her fictional Sophia may in fact be a real person that she is descended from. Carrie meets a local history buff who helps her with some materials, and is also surprised to meet the other son, a history professor, whose quiet charms begin to win her over. The story goes back and forth between the historical story and the contemporary one, with each having a compelling story. Is Carrie channeling the past of her ancestor through some form of genetic memory? It is an interesting blend of history, drama, light romance, and a touch of the fantastical.

I have been trying to get this book for ages because I've read so many wonderful reviews about it.  I now believe they either were relatives or friends of the author.  I have spent a lot of time delving into the history of the Jacobites and thought that this book was about one of those attempts to put a Stuart on the throne.  Alas, it was a romantic story within a romantic story.  The story is simple, not interesting, and I finally forced myself to get through the book because I paid for it, otherwise I would have stopped.  The characters have absolutely no build-up.  I couldn't tell one from the other.  They all lacked personalities.  Aside from one character, who spoke Doric, the other Scots spoke like they had been born in London or New York.  As it was explained in the book, the author within the author, "said that her readers wouldn't like it if she wrote their speech as if they were Scots."  That didn't stop Ms. Gabaldon.  This book and this author has been compared to DuMaurier, Seton, Gabaldon.  Shows you what a good publicist can do for an author.  No comparison.  The book was boring, uninteresting, no Jacobite history but for one page in which the romantic lead,who's an historian, explains where the word "Jacobite" comes from and the family tree.  Really, I don't want to continue on except to say that I hope Ms. Kearsley's other books are better but I will not spend good money to find out.

good read, however, not very believable when the author has the main character, the mother, leave her only child.  No mother would so callously leave her baby.  Every mother understands this common basic .

I enjoined this book and found it interesting in how the author intertwined her story with the writer and the plot. I enjoyed the history and the detail descriptions of the bay. It was an enjoyable read.

This was a great read!  At first I thought it would be too long but after I got started I couldn't stop.  Fantastic writing!  This book will take you through all your emotions and leave you wanting more.

Susanna Kearsley is a talented, imaginative historical fiction author! She weaves the fight for Scotland's independence together with an unforgettable love story that transcends time in The Winter Sea.
She has tremendous talent in her genre and is a master at blending history, mystery, and romance. The Winter Sea is one of her very best--and that is saying a lot because she is very, very good!
this was amazing on so many levels. I couldn't put it down. the writing was phenomenal...beautiful. Very much worth the time to read and something I would actually want to read more than once!!
Great blend of historical romance and modern romance. Such good writing with wonderfully drawn characters. And the best part is the ending that made me cry happy tears. I loved this book.
I truly enjoyed this novel and was so pleased to read that there were actual historical events throughout. Susanna Kearsey  swept me away to Scotland with a gentle, heartwarming tale.

THE WINTER SEA by Susanna Kearsley is a historical fiction/romance set in present day Scotland and 1708 Scotland. It is well written with depth,details,twists and turns. It is an epic love story...It intertwines the present and past with interesting,heartbreaking,and enchanting characters. It has romance, love, passion for country,Scots,ancestry, suspense,destiny,betrayal,sacrifice,and the haunting tale of true love and sacrifice. Carrie goes to Scotland to research her next historical novel based on the 1708 Jacobite Rebellion and she finds so much more.....She has visions of things from the past, one of her ancestors,Sophia while writing her new novel. She learns of her families past, while engaging in her own future with someone similar to Sophia's new love.This is an epic tale of love,history,romance and the drama of the past. This is a don't miss historical full of tear jerking moments and a wonderful surprise at the end. I would highly recommend this book especially if you enjoy history, Scotland,romance, and an epic tale of love and sacrifice. This book was received for the purpose of review from the publisher and details can be found at Sourcebooks Landmark and My Book Addiction and More.
Was looking for something to fill my time until Diana Gabaldon's  latest was released.  Was very pleasantly surprised with this gem.  Can't wait to read more from Susanna Kearsley.
I really enjoyed this book.  It was written from an interesting point of view and it was hard to put down.  I did guess the ending, however, but it didn't ruin anything for me.
Loved every bit of it! Writing is superb and the storyline grabbed me from the first paragraph! This story is smart, funny, sad, and a real page-turner. Kudos to Ms Kearsley!
Hide in your room from your kids with a dish of ice cream and enjoy this delicious story.  At least that is what I did to enjoy the last chapter.  Lovely historical fiction.
A wonderful and entertaining read. The history woven into the story was especially interesting. Loved the characters and am looking forward to reading more Susanna Kearsley.
The characters and settings are vivid and memorable.  Kearsley's writing style is poetic.  I really enjoyed the historical portion although I do not read historical novels.

There are definitely good things about this book. First and foremost it is well written in a technical sense. Unlike so many books these days I didn't find myself cringing at awful grammatical errors or just plain bad writing. The story itself was interesting, and I didn't find the jumps between centuries hard to follow. Unfortunately, the main characters failed to come alive for me. Ms. Kearsley failed to describe the two heroines at all, I had no mental picture of them. I also failed to understand why one, let alone more than one, suitors would fall for each of them after a few brief encounters. Their personalities seemed so run of the mill, they were perfectly fine, but not especially interesting. And there was zero passion between the lovers, and the love scenes, such as they were, were the opposite of sexy. They were sex-less. One plot device annoyed me...if you're living in a huge castle with a creepy pervert gardener who has threatened you, why would you use the same garden for secret rendezvous with your lover? Isn't that what stables are for? Or a dark corner closet? All in all, an okay read. It kept me interested, but I will not be reading more of this author's works. 3.5 stars.
Great book.  Want to use for book club.  So far everyone I know who has read it, "loved it" and missed the characters when the book was over.  Buy it.  It is worth it.
I loved this book.  It was well written with realistic characters.  I did not find a slow  part in  the adventure which is common in other books.  A real page turner.
The book is very well researched.  It takes you directly into the story and makes you feel as if you are living the story.  Kearsley is a very talented story teller.

I am a huge fan of historical fiction. Nothing engrosses me as much as reading about a bygone era that is interwoven with tales of love and loss. That being said, I truly did like The Winter Sea, but it didn't grab and captivate me the way that I wanted it to. Susanna Kearsley's writing style is quite beautiful and her research of the time frame was obviously tremendous. I loved the characters of Sophia and Mr. Moray. Their romance was thrilling and the historical backdrop was exciting. I felt like I was transported to Slains, something that I feel is a hallmark of an excellent historical fiction piece. What brought the novel down a few notches for me was the back and forth pacing between the past and the present. I feel like the constant jumping around interrupted the flow of the book. I also did not particularly connect to Carrie, the writer who is channeling Sophia's voice. While Sophia is vulnerable and vibrant, I felt like Carrie was more of one note. Her romance was nice, but not electrifying like that of her ancestor's. Regardless, I am happy that I read this novel. It was fun and I learned quite a bit. Kearsley is a talented writer.
Great time travel/Historical fiction book with a nice love story intertwined. Read it for book club and everyone enjoyed it. It's pretty long but worth the read.
Very excellent historical fiction.  I like the accuracy of the historical facts.  Characters were believable for the time period in which the story takes place.

"The Winter Sea" was my first Susanna Kearsley novel and will not be my last.  I loved her mix of history and romance.  I was also impressed with the meta-fiction element: an author writing a novel about the author's ancestor; two interwoven tales that stay remarkably grounded despite the fantastical element.  Kearsley moves between the two main characters (Carrie and her ancestor Sophia) with ease, linking together small details and creating a memorable and moving story.  I found the plot somewhat predictable (not just the historical aspect, the literary one as well) and the reading easy going.  However, the simplistic use of language (with the exception of the Doric) and plot did not "dumb down" the telling.  I thought it merely showcased the characters themselves, drawing you in and leaving you touched my their stories.  I also enjoyed learning historical details of the Jacobite "invasion".  A good way to spend some leisure time and a good book to add to my personal library.  And made me desperately wish I could finally see Scotland for myself (the land of my ancestors) instead of always just reading about it.
Sweet chatacters, great storyline. I love the history in it too. I was not fully clear on the Jacobite rebellion but it was actually not crucial to the story.
interesting read but bogged down a bit too much with historical references which were hard to keep err p straight.  author shone when sticking to romances-.

This book was suggested to me as being one I would like since I had read Jennifer Donnelly's Tea Rose series, and I thought 4.5 stars with 371 reviews...you can't go wrong.  However, I have tried to read this book several times and have gotten so bored by it that I will probably give up.  The writing is just so flat and doesn't draw you in.  I really don't like giving up on books because I kind of consider it to be a personal failure if I do, and there are definitely examples of extraordinary books that just start out slow (take Girl with the Dragon Tattoo for example).  But usually if I've gotten a good fourth or third of the way through the book and something hasn't changed to draw me in, I will consider it to be a lemon after all, which I think this book is unfortunately.

I was reading this book when I started this review because I wanted to jot down a few ideas while they were fresh. First thing to note is that it's not technically a time travel book (this is not a spoiler). The time travel consists of the character traveling in her thoughts to write a book but the connection is stronger than you might think. Secondly the history is a bit more complicated to follow in this one than The Rose Garden. It wasn't difficult to follow in The Rose Garden. Then again The Rose Garden took me about seven chapters before I was hooked. I'm only on page 90 currently so I have faith in the author. Continuing reading... it's page 133 where it takes the turn for me. Now that I'm done...What an emotional and fantastically written novel! It's not going to be for everyone - I love history so this did not dissuade me - it was like getting two books for the price of one!! Carrie as the author, and Sophia as the historical character - what a well written connection between the two. The brothers were endearing, and I was very fond of the ending!

I feel really badly about writing a 1 star review. I NEVER give books a 1 star review. However, with this book I had to force myself to keep my eyes on the words, and I did not finish the story. I got about halfway through and reminded myself that life is far too short to read boring books. The heroine is about as engaging as a dishtowel, and for the life of me I could not figure out what the plot was. Then it dawned on me...there wasn't one. This book had all the makings of something I SHOULD have enjoyed reading, but I'm afraid it fell short. It just is so slow. I totally understand that the author has to build up a world, but my gosh the Egyptians built the pyramids faster than this author got to the point. Oh, also, the characters spoke with a Scottish accent and the author wrote it that way, and it made me want to gag. I can't explain way--it was just annoying. I have nothing against Scottish accents being written in books (you are looking at a huge Jamie Fraser fan), but this one was just not done well. So...yeah...maybe try reading something else.

I don't think I'm the right audience for this one. Rather than rehash plot points, I'll just say that the historical-fiction plot had me scanning quickly in several spots; I couldn't be bothered to care about the intrigue and political plotting, and I found it not worth bothering to follow in many points. Also, I read the "surprise twist ending" coming from the very first moment the 18th century characters met (that said, there was a twist about 2/3 of the way through that left me wondering if I was right. I was. And I really didn't like Carrie, the novelist protagonist; how's that for utterly subjective? All of this grumbling aside, however, I have to confess that the last 40 or so pages of the book did have me on the edge of my seat and almost rethinking my initial eyeroll reaction. In sum: I had to push myself to read the first several hundred overwrought pages, but the ending was worth it. And there are a few side characters who I really liked and would have liked to see more of. Do I recommend it? Worth picking up as a beach read, I think.

I bought this on Audible.com and downloaded to my Kindle after reading that "If you liked Diana Gabaldon, you'll like...".  This book was structurally weak as it departs fatally from either a romance or historical romance format.  The prose was absolutely agonizing which was compounded by the highly melodramatic reader.  I agree with the other "1" reviews...boring and could not proceed despite my feeling like I had to read it because I spent money on it. If you want to read some amazing historical fiction read Anya Seton's "Katherine" or any of her titles.  Peace.
I could not put this book down! The story setting is beautiful and mysterious. The story includes history, mystery, and romance. A truly great read.

I enjoyed The Winter Sea and had a difficult time putting it down.  I only wish I knew this was part of a series, and that it would have been noted on the book.  Since I read The Firebird first, the ending in The Winter Sea did not surprise me and move me as much had I not known what was to come.  As always Susanna Kearsley's vivid descriptions and wonderfully developed characters allow the reader to be in the book alongside her amazing characters.  The dialogue throughout the book was brilliantly written - allowing the reader to be submerged into the story.  This book made me laugh and cry.  I loved all the characters.  Sophia and Moray were my favorite.  The connection between Graham and Carrie wasn't developed as well and felt rushed.  The storyline was fabulous.  Kearsley always does a seamless job intertwining the present with the past.  I was sad to say good-bye to the characters of this book.  Again, really disappointed I read The Firebird first!!!  Please make note to readers if books are in a series even if they could be read alone!!!
I enjoyed this book of historical fiction.  It was a interesting read.  I think I enjoyed it so much because it reminded me of my time in Scotland.
Weaving two books together was a first for me. I did thoroughly this book and becoming deeply involved with both main characters and their hero's.
This book was brilliantly written. She could go to the past and back to the now in a blink of an eye. I intend to read more of Kearsleys' novels.
This was an excellent read and Ms. Kearsley truly keeps one wanting more.  I have since ordered her previous books and am enjoying them equally.
This is the first book I've read by Kearsley. I was blown away by it. Just an amazing story, one that stays with you long after you put it down.
Very good read. Interesting. Sweet romance with good transitions between eras. I bought The Rose Garden because this was so good. Recommended.

The book has an intriguing premise: can a fiction writer really see and feel an ancestor's experiences through genetic memory by being in the same places she experienced them?  Carrie comes to Scotland doing research for her book on the 1708 Jacobite rebellion and starts to know Sophia's story and write it all down.  She knows she's researched some of the basics, but she knows details about lives and it's uncanny how the details keep being proved correct.  It's a great book that alternates between Carrie's story and Sophia's story in 1708.  It's a romantic story as both are drawn to unlikely loves.  It's also a tale of intrigue and suspense as the events of the rebellion unfold and Scots nobles try to return King James to the throne.  It's well-researched historical fiction told in an engaging and often mesmerizing way and the characters are worth reading about and caring for, in both centuries.  I liked this one better than "The Rose Garden" by the same author and I thought that one was great.

For 3/4 of "The Winter Sea" I was ready to give this book 5*.  The author slips between present and several centuries ago so easily and so convincingly. Tho' I knew she was supposedly writing about the past I believed it.  And I loved the present.  I loved the descriptions and the idea of genetic memory.  What fun!  But about 3/4 of the way thru, it began to be repetitive.  It dragged.  The past got too detailed about battles and genealogy.  And, in short, I did not believe the ending.  The present was too pat, and the past was unsatisfactory.  But if I'd stopped reading it about 100 pages before it ended I found it so mesmerizing and fascinating and beautifully written that I'd have given it 5*, but it bogged down. It got like Scotland - grey and monochromatic.  Also, tho the history was great, it eventually lost me, and it ended up being one dimensional in that it was just a Romance.  An unflagging one dimensional romance.
Simply fantastic! Rich locations, fantastic character development and full of history and romance. She sounds a story you hate to put down
What a great little find.. a well told story with interesting characters ... I'm downloading he next book.. So,so good thank you Ms Young
The author is an artist.  She paints an amazingly vivid picture of the current and past Scots and their homeland.  Couldn't put it down.

I looked at this book twenty times before I decided to read it.  The comparisons to Diana Gabaldon's "Outlander" put me off because I love that series so much and didn't want to read a weak plotted ghost.  Not so!  The plot was so tight and tied up at the end to the last tiny knot.  Two stories in one and instead of being aggravated when the segments switched, I couldn't wait because both storylines were breathtaking.  The characters will live on in my mind.  Geez, even the dogs will live on in my mind.  I was with Jane all the way at the end and I was glad that Carrie listened to her.  I cried, I clenched, I yelled out loud.  I cheered Uncle Patrick and I wanted to shove Stuie down a flight of steps.  It wasn't "Outlander" but it was very, very, very good.  Books of this quality are few and far between.  I even sat on the internet and looked at Cruden Bay and the ruins at Slains.  Few books entice me to that extent.  Read it...don't miss it...you'll love it.
Really enjoyed this historic romance novel. I especially loved the developement of the caracters in different time periods and ending
I Loved the connection between past and present, the detailed and intriguing history, plus of course the good old-fashioned romance.

What a Great Read!!! The Winter Sea has everything I like in a book, only this is even better because it's two stories wrapped up into one, with not one, but two heartswooning romances, and two happy endings! I've read other novels that flip back and forth between historical and present-day storylines, and in all of those instances I slogged through the present-day chapters longing to get back to the history. But in this case I enjoyed the present day story just as much as the past. I loved how the author wove the past and the present together as Carrie dreamed of the Jacobite invasion, finding inspiration for her novel, and then in her research discovered that her dreams were more than just dreams. I found that I really enjoyed reading about a fiction writer, and of course, I love anything set in Scotland! And it made me cry. I didn't want it to end. Very well done Ms. Kearsley! I've added all of her other books to my wishlist.
The history, setting, and two storylines were beautifully described!  I will read more from Kearsley now.  Very well written book.
This story took me to a place I would love to visit some day.  It may not exist but this story does and it was very entertaining.
It flowed wonderfully. It was a great mixture of romance and history, also a bit of fantasy. Definitely liking the authors style.
Lovely read. Enjoyed the history and the romance. Kearney is a very prolific writer who envelops you in every word. A must read
Very good, liked the book.  A bit too much genealogy.  Liked the two parallel stories.  Would recommend to friends.  Nice read.
Bought this for my great aunt as a Christmas present. She loves it so much, she has ordered the rest of Susana Kearsley's work.
I HAD A HARD TIME FINISHING THIS BOOK AND WOULD NOT RECOMMEND IT. I SELECT BOOKS BASED ON RATINGS AND THIS ONE MISSED THE MARK.

This book is my third favorite of Kearsley's (1. The Rose Garden 2. Mariana). It starts off a little slowly, and if you're not up on the era you might need to keep a British monarchy family tree (1603-1710 James I-George I) handy to follow the politics. But once the author's traditional unexplained happenings begin it really takes off. Carrie, an historical fiction author, begins a book set at Scotland's Slaines Castle in 1707. She soon discovers, when she stops to do some research, that what she is writing is actually what happened -- right down to the historical characters names, movements, motives and vessel names! The love story for the author is not hard to figure out, the one in the novel she's writing is lovely, then tragic and heartbreaking. In true Kearsley fashion, there is a stunning plot twist at the end that I didn't see coming. This was also published with the title Sofia's Secret.
This book kept me engaged the entire time. The character development was outstanding.  I would recommend this book. Well done
Well written complex story with two settings of past and present.  Two romances and political intrigue, and a very good read!
Interesting plot development and intriguing characters. Liked how it all came full circle.  Not too far fetched of an ending
Great book, I will be reading more of Susanna Kearsley books. Enjoy historical novels very much. Thanks to Susanna Kearsley.
Nice story set in Scotland, easy to follow, easy to read.  If you like Outlander you will like this-same period in history

I will start off my review by stating that I am a fan of historical fiction.  Among other authors, I have read several of Philippa Gregory's books and was pretty much captivated by them.  I read the reviews for The Winter Sea, and was expecting a great read.  Unfortunately I was so bored, I had to force myself to finish the book and I'm not glad I did.  I feel like I wasted my time. The writing is fine, but I kept waiting for something to happen and it never does. I am also a fan of Anita Shreve; her books just flow along and I actually have liked all that I have read, so it's not the style that bothered me. I mean you have an old castle, Scotland, the sea... how could I be so bored?  When I'm listening to a book and my mind is wondering to chores and work, I know I'm not interested. If you're looking for a book you can't put down, you might want to look elsewhere.

Miss Kearsley uses an interesting literary device to tell a dual story of romance, one in modern day Scotland and the other in Scotland 200 years ago,  Carrie Maclelland visits her agent in Scotland and falls in love with and in Scotland.  Historical facts that she should not have known came bubbling up as she stayed in a cottage next to a castle named Slains by the sea.  Carrie is a writer of historical fiction but her book quickly became more than fiction.  The story is about a girl named Sophie who met a Jacobite soldier at Slains.
